review.title: Less is More: Building Selective Anomaly Ensembles
review.abstract: Ensemble techniques for classification and clustering have long proven effective, yet anomaly ensembles have been barely studied. In this work, we tap into this gap and propose a new ensemble approach for anomaly mining, with application to event detection in temporal graphs. Our method aims to combine results from heterogeneous detectors with varying outputs, and leverage the evidence from multiple sources to yield better performance. However, trusting all the results may deteriorate the overall ensemble accuracy, as some detectors may fall short and provide inaccurate results depending on the nature of the data in hand. This suggests that being selective in which results to combine is vital in building effective ensembles---hence "less is more".

metadata.title: Less is More: Building Selective Anomaly Ensembles with Application to Event Detection in Temporal Graphs

sections.text: In this article, we propose SELECT, an ensemble approach to anomaly mining that uses novel techniques to automatically and systematically select the results, which are then assembled completely unsupervised. We apply our method to event detection in time charts, with SELECT successfully deploying five base detectors and seven consensus methods within a unified ensemble framework. We provide comprehensive quantitative evaluation of our approach using five real-world datasets (four of them with ground truth), including Enron email communications, New York Times news corpus, and Twitter news feed for the 2014 World Cup. Thanks to its selection mechanism, SELECT achieves superior performance compared to individual detectors alone, the entire ensemble (naively combining all results), and an existing diversity-based ensemble.

sections.text: We evaluate our selective ensemble approach based on the event, using five real-world datasets that we have collected both previously and newly, including email communications, news corporations, and social media. For four of these datasets, we have compiled basic truths for the temporal anomalies for which we present quantitative results. We use the remaining data to illustrate case studies. We compare the performance of SELECT with vertical selection (SelectV), and horizontal selection with that of individual detectors, the entire ensemble without selection (Full), and the diversity-based ensemble (DivE), making us one of the few works that quantitatively compare and contrast ensembles on an order of magnitude that so many datasets with Bodentruth illustrate. sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have proposed SELECT, a new selective ensemble approach to anomaly mining, and applied it to the problem of event detection in time charts. SELECT is a two-phase approach that combines multiple detector results and then multiple consensus. Motivated by our earlier observations [22] that inaccurate detectors can worsen overall ensemble accuracy, we have designed two unattended selection strategies, SelectV and SelectH, which carefully select which detector / consensus is composed. We have compared SELECT with Full, the ensemble that combines all results, and DivE, an existing ensemble [24] that combines diverse, i.e. least correlated, results. Our quantitative evaluation of real-world data sets with the truth on the ground shows that building selective ensembles is effective when it comes to increasing detection performance [8] when selectivity strategy appears to be better than selectivity strategy (where selectivity strategy H seems to be better).

sections.heading: A.5 Moving Average based Event Detection (MAED).
sections.text: MAED is a simple approach that calculates the moving mean of µt and the moving standard deviation σt of each time series corresponding to each node by extending the time window by one point each. If, at any given time, the value removes more than three moving standard deviations from the mean, then the point is considered abnormal and assigned to a value that is not zero. The abnormality value is the difference between the baseline value and (µt + 3σt) at t. To evaluate the time points collectively, MAED aggregates their values across all rows. For each abnormal time t й, the mapping is done by sorting the nodes (i.e. the series) based on the individual values they assign to t.

metadata.abstractText: Ensemble techniques for classification and clustering have long proven effective, yet anomaly ensembles have been barely studied. In this work, we tap into this gap and propose a new ensemble approach for anomaly mining, with application to event detection in temporal graphs. Our method aims to combine results from heterogeneous detectors with varying outputs, and leverage the evidence from multiple sources to yield better performance. However, trusting all the results may deteriorate the overall ensemble accuracy, as some detectors may fall short and provide inaccurate results depending on the nature of the data in hand. This suggests that being selective in which results to combine is vital in building effective ensembles—hence “less is more”. In this paper we propose SELECT; an ensemble approach for anomaly mining that employs novel techniques to automatically and systematically select the results to assemble in a fully unsupervised fashion. We apply our method to event detection in temporal graphs, where SELECT successfully utilizes five base detectors and seven consensus methods under a unified ensemble framework. We provide extensive quantitative evaluation of our approach on five realworld datasets (four with ground truth), including Enron email communications, New York Times news corpus, and World Cup 2014 Twitter news feed. Thanks to its selection mechanism, SELECT yields superior performance compared to individual detectors alone, the full ensemble (naively combining all results), and an existing diversity-based ensemble.
